title: Big tech companies race to do M&A deals
text:
A sign for International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) stands outside offices at the Moscow International Business Center, also known as "Moscow City," in Moscow, Russia, on Sunday, March 16, 2014. (Photo: Andrey Rudakov, Bloomberg)
3 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Long-time technology firms cannot be wallflowers in what appears to be an accelerating dance of mergers and acquisitions.
Four companies found new partners Wednesday in sizable deals: Western Digital increased its power in the memory market by acquiring competitor SanDisk for $19 billion, while LAM Research snatched up KLA Tencor for $10.6 billion in a merging of two semiconductor companies.
This follows last week's blockbuster $67 billion acquisition by computer giant Dell and private-equity firm Silver Lake of data storage company EMC, the largest deal in the history of the tech industry.
Expect to see the M&A dance floor get more crowded as tech firms look for ways to grow, says Daniel Ives, senior research analyst at FBR Capital Markets. "A lot of these companies are seeing a bipolar spending environment and the boards and the CEOs are taking off the rose-colored glasses and they are making the tough decisions, realizing it's either get acquired or strategically buckle up and get ready for the next growth phase, which could be these companies … making acquisitions themselves," he said.
Among tech giants possibly looking for growth through M&A:
IBM ( IBM ). Even though Big Blue scooped up software Meteorix last month, the company has challenges, Ives says. "They are trying to sell Humvees and big gas guzzlers where IT managers and CIOs are looking for Teslas," he said. "That’s where a lot of these tech giants find themselves. They are not ready for this evolving IT environment and they really have missed out along with their tech brethren." His possible targets for IBM include cloud data companies Salesforce.com and security company Palo Alto Networks.
Oracle ( ORCL ). Rumors have been out there that CEO Larry Ellison might attempt to acquire competitor Salesforce, while Forrester Research CEO George Colony told Bloomberg Tuesday that Oracle might still try to outbid Dell for EMC. Oracle, a provider of database software, is losing customers because "enterprise and governments are starting to move away from as more of the budget dollars (go to) cloud, cybersecurity and big data," Ives said. It could duke it out for the same firms IBM might be eyeing, he says, as well as enterprise software company Workday and big data company Splunk.

Cisco ( CSCO ). Another IT company that's lagged in innovation, Ives says. The San Jose, Calif.-based firm company could look to acquire security company Fireeye.
"M&A has been a bit slow to date and it’s about to significantly heat up," Ives said. "A lot of these tech players don't want to find themselves without a dance partner."
The semiconductors industry, in particular, has been a hotbed of consolidation and isn't likely to slow.
Back in May, there were two notable recent chipmaker mergers: Avago's $37 billion Broadcom acquisition and Intel's $17 billion bid for Altera. And on Monday, chipmaker Microsemi made a $2.2 billion bid for fellow Calif.-based chip company PMC-Sierra, outbidding a $2 billion offer from Skyworks Solutions from earlier in the month. "We continue to believe that Semiconductor companies beyond Microsemi will look for scale and target companies" that have good synergies, said RBC Capital Markets analyst Mitch Steves in a note on Monday.
Other potential semiconductor targets include Maxim, SemTech, Power Integrations and Cypress, he said.
A recent FBR & Co. report found that about 11% of U.S. semiconductor companies were acquired in 2014, FBR & Co. said, and about one third of all U.S. publicly-traded semiconductor companies would be acquired this year at the current rate of consolidation. FBR identified additional targets including Advanced Micro Circuits Corp., Lattice Semiconducting Corp, Cavium and Marvell Technology Group.
M&A benefits can include lowering expenses by, for example, reducing management costs and redundant R&D, as well as increasing production efficiencies. A recent FBR & Co. report found that recent tech deals eliminated more than 10% of expenses in large acquisitions and as much as 20% in smaller acquisitions.
Western Digital CEO Steve Milligan told CNBC Wednesday that the company aims to realize $500 million in financial synergies from the SanDisk deal. "We are very comfortable with the long-term view ... and the perspective of the combined company," he said.
The deal will "position (WD-SanDisk) for further growth opportunities going forward," Milligan said. "Fundamentally, this transaction is all about the growth in digital data that all of us are seeing."
